llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: path_injection", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The payload '../../../../etc/passwd%00' is a classic path traversal and null byte injection sequence. The presence of this exact value in the 'title' field of a 200 OK response indicates: (1) The backend accepted unauthorized directory traversal characters without sanitization or rejection, (2) The null byte (%00) suggests an attempt to terminate file extensions, validating this was a path injection test. In GraphQL contexts, this implies the 'createTodo' resolver likely uses user-input to construct file paths without security validation. If this title is used in any file operations (e.g., writing/reading task attachments), it would enable accessing/overwriting system files like /etc/passwd.", "evidence": "The 'title' field successfully stored '../../../../etc/passwd%00' as a filename value", "confidence": 0.8, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "path_injection", "severity": "CRITICAL", "confidence": 0.8, "evidence": "The 'title' field successfully stored '../../../../etc/passwd%00' as a filename value", "explanation": "The payload '../../../../etc/passwd%00' is a classic path traversal and null byte injection sequence. The presence of this exact value in the 'title' field of a 200 OK response indicates: (1) The backend accepted unauthorized directory traversal characters without sanitization or rejection, (2) The null byte (%00) suggests an attempt to terminate file extensions, validating this was a path injection test. In GraphQL contexts, this implies the 'createTodo' resolver likely uses user-input to construct file paths without security validation. If this title is used in any file operations (e.g., writing/reading task attachments), it would enable accessing/overwriting system files like /etc/passwd."}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: html_injection", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The response demonstrates an HTML injection vulnerability where user-supplied input containing an active HTML payload (<iframe> with JavaScript execution) is directly reflected in the API output. This indicates insufficient input sanitization. If a client application renders this payload without proper escaping, it can lead to stored Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks, enabling arbitrary script execution in users' browsers. While the vulnerability exploitation depends on client-side rendering, the API's storage and reflection of unfiltered HTML/JS establishes a clear risk.", "evidence": "The 'title' field contains: \"<iframe src='javascript:alert(1)'></iframe>\"", "confidence": 0.85, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "html_injection", "severity": "HIGH", "confidence": 0.85, "evidence": "The 'title' field contains: \"<iframe src='javascript:alert(1)'></iframe>\"", "explanation": "The response demonstrates an HTML injection vulnerability where user-supplied input containing an active HTML payload (<iframe> with JavaScript execution) is directly reflected in the API output. This indicates insufficient input sanitization. If a client application renders this payload without proper escaping, it can lead to stored Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks, enabling arbitrary script execution in users' browsers. While the vulnerability exploitation depends on client-side rendering, the API's storage and reflection of unfiltered HTML/JS establishes a clear risk."}}]
